executive_summary: The Cocoa and Drinking Chocolate Production industry processes cacao beans and other ingredients to make a powder that can be mixed with a liquid to create a chocolatey beverage. Industry products are distributed to wholesalers, retailers and other intermediaries for resale to consumers. Over the five years to 2021, the industry has benefited from trends including improving disposable incomes and greater demand for premium chocolate goods. However, other trends, such as volatile cocoa prices and rising health consciousness, have limited industry revenue growth. Overall, IBISWorld expects industry revenue to decline an annualized 0.4% to $938.5 million over the five years to 2021, including a projected decline of 0.1% in 2020 due to the rapid deterioration of downstream demand stemming from the recent COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic. However, the industry is expected to bounce back with growth of 2.3% in 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue growth declined in 2020 due to COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Revenue for the Cocoa and Drinking Chocolate Production industry contracted slightly over the five years to 2021. The industry's manufacturers experienced a downturn in 2020 as manufacturing activity decreased rapidly due to restrictions stemming from COVID-19 (coronavirus), while broader demand sputtered due to economic slowdown. As a result, IBISWorld industry revenue declined an estimated 0.1% in 2020, although it is expected to bounce back with growth of 2.3% in 2021.

Over the past five years, the industry's performance with regard to health has had dueling effects. A large number of consumers have adopted healthy eating trends and have become more cautious about eating excessive amounts of sugar, curbing industry demand and revenue. In response, some cocoa and drinking chocolate producers have developed new products with lower sugar and fat content, including specialty and high-end cocoa and drinking chocolate.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Revenue expected to grow 1.6% annually to 2026
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The outlook for the Cocoa and Drinking Chocolate Production industry is relatively sweet. The industry is projected to benefit from ongoing demand for chocolate, including premium varieties, over the five years to 2026. As a result, revenue is forecast to increase at an annualized rate of 1.6% to $1.0 billion over the five years to 2026.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Health consciousness to drive product innovation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: IBISWorld expects consumers to become even more health conscious over the next five years, pushing industry producers to develop new products. Specifically, dark, organic, unprocessed and fair-trade cocoa and drinking chocolate are anticipated to be more popular as a result of widespread health awareness.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Profit margins expected to increase marginally
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Stable cocoa prices are good news for small chocolate producers that are generally less able to pass high costs downstream and end up absorbing these costs. Thus, industry profit is expected to marginally increase over the next five years.

industry_definition: This industry primarily produces hot chocolate, which is also known as hot cocoa or drinking chocolate. Industry operators generally process cacao beans and other ingredients to make a powder that is then mixed with a liquid, such as milk or water. This industry does not produce syrup that is poured into milk to make hot chocolate. Ready-to-drink dairy-based chocolate milk products are also excluded.
key_trends: Some industry operators have developed new products with lower sugar and fat content
The prices of key inputs have been volatile due to fluctuating harvest conditions
Domestic operators have experienced decreased international competition
IBISWorld expects consumers to become even more health conscious
Consumers have become more informed about exploitative treatment of cocoa farmers
Industry profit is expected to marginally increase over the next five years

market_segmentation.segment_description: Confectionery wholesalers purchase drinking chocolate from manufacturers and distribute it to retailers.
Supermarkets and grocery stores serve as the most important retail channel for end consumers to purchase hot chocolate.
Specialty retailers include bakeries, cafes, chocolatiers that purchase cocoa as ingredients or for resale. Also includes online stores and convenience stores.
Includes purchases from catalogs, store-fronts or online ordering systems of small and medium businesses.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand is determined by the level of consumer disposable income. When consumers have more spending money, they are likely to increase spending on discretionary goods like cocoa and drinking chocolate.

Demand is affected by consumer health trends. Consumers have become more health conscious, cutting foods high in sugar, fat and calories. Producers have developed healthier options like organic cocoa and lower sugar products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imports satisfy an estimated 34.6% of domestic demand in 2021. The value of imports has declined 7.9% annually over 5 years due to volatility in world cocoa prices. Major import sources are the Netherlands (55.3%), Mexico (12.7%), Malaysia (12.4%) and France (9.2%).

Exports generate 12.0% of industry revenue in 2021. Export value has risen 2.1% annually over 5 years. A stronger US dollar discourages exports as US products become more expensive. Major export destinations are Canada (43.1%), Mexico (24.3%), China (3.2%) and South Korea (2.6%).

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA monitors nutritional and health claims put on labels by industry operators. The FDA also instituted the Food Ingredient Safety Program, which governs and evaluates claims made by manufacturers about ingredients and nutritional content.

The Environmental Protection Agency and state governments enforce environmental issues pertaining to food processing industries. Federal environmental regulations and statutes, such as the Clean Water Act (CWA) and Clean Air Act regulate how facilities handle products and waste.
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) sets and regulates standards for safe and healthy working conditions for employees in manufacturing industries.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, increasing barriers to entry.
The industry has a high concentration level, increasing barriers.
The industry has a low level of technology change, decreasing barriers.

basis_points.basis_description: Product quality greatly affects pricing and demand. Higher quality products can demand higher prices. Quality differentiated by type of chocolate, flavor, and specialized processes.
Source and quality of ingredients becoming more important to consumers. Demand growing for sustainable and ethical products.
Cost-conscious consumers seek value in lower-end products (price competition). Brand reputation offers identifiable way to discern between products.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four major players are expected to generate 78.6% of industry revenue in 2021.
The top three producers offer low-cost hot chocolate which has declined in popularity, while niche operators for premium products have increased.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs represent the largest expense category for industry operators, accounting for 53.1% of revenue in 2021. The price of key inputs is largely determined on world markets and depends on global supply and demand conditions, and therefore, it can be highly volatile.

Depreciation costs are expected to account for 2.2% of industry revenue in 2021 and reflects expenditure on fixed assets, such as plants, machinery and other equipment. Depreciation as a share of revenue has remained relatively steady over the past five years.

Marketing costs are expected to account for 0.6% of revenue in 2021. Despite the significant investments that larger companies make, smaller companies generally do not spend as much on advertising as they serve a smaller geographic area than multinational chocolate producers.
Rent expenses account for 1.3% of industry revenue in 2021. Operators require work facilities that are large enough for them to house the equipment needed to make chocolate.
Operators need a fair amount of electricity, heating, cooling and energy to produce industry products. As a result, utility expenses account for 1.0% of industry revenue in 2021.
Other costs are expected to account for 13.7% of industry revenue in 2021 and include distribution, packaging and research and development.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Capital intensity varies by company size
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Small- and medium-sized facilities tend to spend less on capital because they lack the resources to invest in expensive technology and equipment. Moreover, smaller operators generally focus on artisan production, eliminating the need for machines.
Modern manufacturing plants use sophisticated technology and equipment that increase productivity without the need for additional labor, thereby reducing operating costs.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is subject to changes in the cost of raw materials, energy and oil prices, per capita disposable income and changes in demand from consumer markets.
The price of cocoa has been central to industry volatility, causing operators to raise prices intermittently to account for hikes in the cost of cocoa.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry has improved the automation of its processes, using instruments to stabilize conditions in the production process. These monitored and controlled conditions reduce the risk of potential issues in the manufacturing process.
Packaging in this industry has improved with greater automation. This has improved the consistency and speed of the packaging process.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries like China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Over the past five years, imports have been declining as consumers are increasingly opting for premium and local hot chocolate varieties. However, imports from Mexico and other lower wage countries do account for a small but significant portion of imports.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators often offer a variety of products. For instance, major player Nestle SA is involved in many food production industries, including chocolate production.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators are investing in research and development to expand existing product lines and offer some more premium varieties.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Two of the industry's key inputs are sugar and cocoa, both of which have experienced large swings over the past five years.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Overall, the Cocoa and Drinking Chocolate Production industry has not adopted much new technology over the past five years. Many are simply working on improving existing processes and adopting automation as part of the packaging process.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: While the industry has not adopted much new technology over the past five years, automation plays a small role in the production process.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Industry goods, such as sweetened cocoa powder, can carry a tariff of up to $0.33 per kilogram. This helps protect Cocoa and Drinking Chocolate producers from foreign competition.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: In 2015, the US Food and Drug Administration announced that trans fat must be phased out by 2018. As a result, industry operators were required to adjust formulas, which negatively impacted profitability.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: As consumers are increasingly adopting healthier lifestyles, demand for industry goods has dwindled, which has placed financial pressure on industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit differs among industry operators depending on their size and the types of cocoa and drinking chocolate goods they produce. Premium industry goods are often able to command higher prices, resulting in higher margins typically.

FAQs.question: How do you remain competitive with other companies in the industry? How are you able to leverage your economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies that are better able to spread costs will likely experience lower costs per-unit.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to promote your company by word-of-mouth recommendations? Have you shifted your brand imagine to reflect changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Consumer perceptions regarding the quality and health considerations of a product factor into the overall demand for a product.

FAQs.question: How do you respond to variability in consumer demand? Are you able to quickly adapt to change and respond to changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Successful companies have the ability to anticipate and respond to changes in consumer preferences in a timely manner, given the seasonal nature of confectionery demand.

FAQs.question: Do you track sugar and sweetener consumption? Have you shifted to producing products for more health-conscious consumers?
FAQs.answer: Per capita sugar and sweetener consumption indicate the level of preference-based demand for chocolate drinks. Recent health trends have stifled consumption of sugar and sweets, which has caused consumers to shy away from cocoa and chocolate drinks.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changes in sugar prices? How do you mitigate revenue declines when the price of sugar declines?
FAQs.answer: Sugar is a key ingredient into cocoa powders; therefore, as the price of this commodity grows, input costs for producers mount. Since many producers of chocolate experience strong brand loyalty, they are more easily able to pass higher costs on and reap higher returns.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor disposable income trends? How do you mitigate declines in revenue when disposable income declines?
FAQs.answer: Drinking chocolate is considered a discretionary good. As disposable income levels rise, demand for cocoa, particularly for premium products, increases. However, consumers also indulge in chocolate products in financial downturns, demonstrating the industry's resilience against economic downfalls.
